messages.message: Looks like we actually got conflicting user feedback here https://instabase.slack.com/archives/C0516UPPMT3/p1702561148974609
@hannah I haven’t updated the copy here yet so lmk if we still want to proceed w the change
Since default drives are a new concept, I think we should leave it for now.

I do think it's worth adding a similar pop-up for converse still to make it a similar experience (@Vasu@Varun Jain). The idea would be that a user sees that same modal with header text and sub-text that is updated for:
> *Default drive changed: Unable to add new files*
> You can continue interacting with files already in this conversation. To converse with new files, create a new conversation.
The user would then see the explanation of default drive and the only option a user would have is to close the modal. If the user went to update files they would then see the banner in converse.

I don't know about this! :face_with_raised_eyebrow: To be fair, @Lee isn't a typical _end user within a commercial org_. For that user, all they need to know is that an org admin changed the default drive, and they can either move their project there or delete it. They don't need a paragraphs of explanation about what a default drive is. As Jean pointed out previously, users understand the concept of _default_ and _drive_.

I'm all for explaining things in the UI when it warrants it, but I think this current modal is overkill given the intended audience. I stand by my recommendation for the Build modal:

*Default drive has changed*
An admin changed the default drive for your organization. You must either migrate this project to the new default drive or delete it.
[Delete project] [Move project]

it’s possible this modal could be re-designed to have this additional info initially collapsed and expandable under a section called something like “what is a default drive?” — or it could link to the docs if there’s information about drives there :shrug::skin-tone-4:
I like either of those options!

I'm down to change this in future releases, but would prefer to have the explanation there for now. Despite "default" and "drive" being words that are recognized, I don't think it's something that our customers will easily understand and would rather err on the side of over explaining here than under explaining esp. given the implications on customer data.

We can also iterate further once we have actual customer feedback.
